description: Root object: presence of purposes for which data is processed

Uses profiling and tracking across services; high risk to privacy and requires informed consent. — May refer to behaviorally targeted advertising, interest-based ads, or profiling for commercial messaging.
Mandatory and legally required notices; minimal privacy risk. — May refer to legal notices, changes to terms, or updates to service agreements.
Covers essential updates (e.g., password resets); low risk as it is necessary and expected. — May refer to transactional messages, account notifications, password resets, or system alerts.
Involves profiling and preferences; requires explicit opt-in to comply with GDPR. — May refer to marketing emails tailored to user interests, behavior, or stated preferences.
Enables user interaction; some risk if contact details or activities are shared unintentionally. — May refer to friend invites, user-to-user messages, or content sharing features.
Non-essential marketing requires consent; high risk if consent is not properly obtained or managed. — May refer to promotional offers, marketing campaigns, or special event communications.
Essential for upholding user rights and lawful processing; minimal privacy impact. — May refer to consent records, cookie preferences, or opt-in/opt-out tracking.

May involve monitoring and profiling, but typically justified for legitimate interests; moderate impact on rights. — May refer to misuse detection, fraud prevention mechanisms, or abuse monitoring systems.
Limited to business context; usually low impact on individuals and clear lawful basis. — May refer to business client onboarding, account administration, or enterprise service provision.
Subcategory: Provide Services and Fulfil Contractual Obligations

Processing is necessary to perform a contract; low risk if data is used solely for this purpose. — May refer to account provision, user authentication, service access, or content delivery essential to user agreement.
Involves technical logging; usually low risk unless logs include personal identifiers. — May refer to system diagnostics, crash reports, error logging, or operational troubleshooting.

Can significantly affect individuals; requires transparency, safeguards, and human review option. — May refer to automated profiling, algorithmic decision-making, or system-based eligibility assessments.
Typically internal and uses limited personal data; safeguards reduce privacy impact. — May refer to internal audits, corporate disclosures, or regulatory compliance tracking.
Necessary to fulfill GDPR obligations; involves identity verification and data handling. — May refer to fulfilling user rights requests such as data access, correction, or deletion.
May require extensive data review or sharing with third parties; can significantly affect rights. — May refer to legal proceedings, complaints management, or regulatory cooperation.

Permissible if based on law or task in public interest; must balance against individual rights. — May refer to public health studies, safety monitoring programs, or legally mandated data use in the public interest.
Retention of data for legal or audit purposes; generally limited in scope but long-term. — May refer to data archiving for legal retention, accounting compliance, or audit preparation.
Processing is mandated by law, often requiring sharing with authorities; impacts data subject rights. — May refer to legal disclosures, subpoenas, or regulatory information sharing.
Often uses pseudonymized or aggregated data; some risk if data is linked to individuals. — May refer to service analytics, feature usage, user flow analysis, or aggregated behavioral trends.
Involves direct feedback and sometimes sensitive opinions; moderate risk depending on consent and purpose. — May refer to feedback collection, usability studies, or market preference inquiries.
Used to minimize data risk; considered a safeguard if re-identification is prevented. — May refer to pseudonymisation processes, masking techniques, or data minimisation practices.
If data is truly anonymized, GDPR does not apply; if pseudonymized, residual risk remains. — May refer to statistical analysis, research using anonymized datasets, or aggregated insights.
Involves sensitive data requiring explicit consent or legal basis; strict safeguards apply. — May refer to handling of sensitive personal data under strict legal or research frameworks.
Security monitoring may involve behavior analysis; risk is mitigated by necessity and safeguards. — May refer to intrusion detection, access logs, security audits, or technical threat mitigation.
Involves processing sensitive reports; medium risk due to potential profiling or misidentification. — May refer to user safety features, content moderation, or reporting mechanisms.
Minimal data use; typically does not impact rights or involve profiling. — May refer to responsive design, screen resolution adjustment, or UI personalization based on device data.

Behavioral tracking can lead to implicit profiling; needs lawful basis and user awareness. — May refer to monitoring user interaction, clickstream analysis, or behavioral data collection within the platform.

Involves profiling that may affect user behavior or choices; requires transparency and potentially consent. — May refer to personalized recommendations, tailored content, or adaptation of user experience based on past behavior or preferences.
